biogHist.abstract: Nazareth House in Bluff Point, Geraldton was established in 1941 and run by the Poor Sisters of Nazareth. Its first residents were children from 1 year old who were private admissions, and 'destitute' aged people. Nazareth House also housed child migrants sent from Britain and Malta (1947-1966), who often lived there for many years. At times, there were between 50 and 75 migrant children living at Nazareth House along with Australian-born children. From 1961, young boys were admitted and from 1965 some Aboriginal children were also placed there. From the late 1970s, no children were admitted to Nazareth House but it continued as an aged care facility.
biogHist.p: Nazareth House, situated on Bluff Point in Geraldton, opened in October 1941. It was initially built in to house children sent as child migrants from Britain. However, as it became unsafe to transport children during the war, the large buildings were used to accommodate children, from the age of 12 months, and old people who were deemed 'destitute'.

Government reports (Signposts 2004, p.367) show that there was an intention, in 1941 at least, to use Nazareth House as a place to house 'Roman Catholic children other than delinquents' from the Geraldton area who were committed to an institution. Nazareth House was licensed to provide 'care' for children under 6 years old, and would be subsidised for admitting children referred through the child welfare authorities or children's court who may have been deemed neglected or removed from their families for other reasons.

From 1947, girls who were sent as unaccompanied child migrants from Britain and Malta were accommodated at Nazareth House, and went to school on the premises. Occasionally, certain girls were chosen to attend the Stella Maris Convent school in Geraldton. They boarded there during term time and returned to Nazareth House for their holidays.

Photographs taken through the years when the migrant girls were at Nazareth House show that the boys from Tardun (one and a half hours east of Geraldton) occasionally visited. These visits must have been particularly important for boys and girls who were siblings.

The admission details provided for Nazareth House in government reports are scant (Signposts pp.367-369) until 1957 when a clearer picture starts to emerge of the number of girls living at Nazareth House.

By 1957, there were 67 girls, some of whom were migrants and others who were 'private admissions' (girls placed by family or others). In some years, girls who were wards of the State were also admitted to Nazareth House. The number of children admitted privately increasingly outweighed the number of girls who were child migrants. In 1961, reports to child welfare authorities documented the number of boys at Nazareth House. These few boys would have been pre-school age in most cases. In 1965, Aboriginal children classified as 'native wards' were shown in admission figures as a small minority of total children accommodated.

There are no published admission figures after 1970, and Nazareth House closed its child accommodation program in the late 1970s. The Catholic guide, A Piece of the Story says that Nazareth House ceased child care activities in 1977, but research for Signposts in 2004 found a reference to Nazareth House in Commonwealth statistics collated in 1979. This could be because Nazareth House was still gazetted as a child care institution, rather than because it actually housed children.
There have always been aged people in residence at Nazareth House (in a separate wing from the children) and in 2014 it continued as an aged care facility.

chronItem.event: Location - Nazareth House provided accommodation in Geraldton

descriptiveNote.p: Ross Fact-Finding Mission [British child migration] The Ross Fact-Finding Mission was interested in the welfare of British child migrants sent to Nazareth House.

Records of child migration to Western Australia, National Archives of Australia (1947 - 1959)
Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection (1894 - )

descriptiveNote.p: Father Hudson's Society was one of the Homes in Britain that sent child migrants to Nazareth House.
Nazareth House was part of the Catholic Immigration Scheme that sent children from Britain and Malta to Western Australia.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association [CEMWA] (1947? - 1970)

descriptiveNote.p: The Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association [CEMWA] was the organisation that coordinated the placement of child migrants to Nazareth House.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Catholic Child Welfare Council, United Kingdom (1929 - 2003)

descriptiveNote.p: The Catholic Child Welfare Council was was involved in sending unaccompanied child migrants to Nazareth House from Britain.
Children classified as 'native wards' were reported in child welfare reports as living in Nazareth House during the 1960s.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: CEMWA Response to Moss Questionnaire

archref.abstract: 'CEMWA Response to Moss Questionnaire' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. There is an undated letter from the Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association Inc, responding to questions about Bindoon, Clontarf, Castledare,Nazareth House, St Joseph's Orphanage (including St Vincent's Foundling Home), and Tardun. There is also a letter, dated 14 August 1951, from the Under Secretary for Lands and Immigration passing on further information about staffing at those institutions.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia

archref.unittitle: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia
archref.abstract: 'Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. It is the questionnaire that was circulated to government, the organisations that received and placed child migrants, and the children's Homes where the children lived. This questionnaire was received by the Commonwealth Government on 10 May 1951.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Nazareth House on the ChapmanRiver, Geraldton, 1946

archref.repository: Government Photographer collection, State Library of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: Nazareth House on the ChapmanRiver, Geraldton, 1946
archref.abstract: This is a digitised copy of a photograph of a photographic print and is part of the Government Photographer collection held at the State Library of Western Australia. The image shows the isolated location of Nazareth House, out on Bluff Point near the Chapman River.
archref.note: This image is for personal use only. To publish or display it, contact the State Library of Western Australia

resourceRelation.relationEntry: John Moss C.B.E. U.K. Child Welfare Expert. Visit to Australia. Part II

archref.unittitle: John Moss C.B.E. U.K. Child Welfare Expert. Visit to Australia. Part II
archref.abstract: This is a file held online by the National Archives of Australia. It has draft reports on the Australian institutions which took unaccompanied British child migrants after World War Two.
